rev.diff:
Line 141: Line 141:
== Releases ==
== Releases ==
  +
{{see|History of Ubuntu releases}}
The Ubuntu project makes two releases per year, using the year and month of the release as a [[version number]]. The first Ubuntu release, for example, was Ubuntu 4.10 and was released on [[October 20]], [[2004]].<ref name="warty_release">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2004-October/000003.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 announcement |date=[[2004-10-20]] |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |authorlink=Mark Shuttleworth }}</ref> Consequently, version numbers for future versions are provisional; if the release is delayed until a different month to that planned, the version number changes accordingly.
The Ubuntu project makes two releases per year, using the year and month of the release as a [[version number]]. The first Ubuntu release, for example, was Ubuntu 4.10 and was released on [[October 20]], [[2004]].<ref name="warty_release">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2004-October/000003.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 announcement |date=[[2004-10-20]] |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |authorlink=Mark Shuttleworth }}</ref> Consequently, version numbers for future versions are provisional; if the release is delayed until a different month to that planned, the version number changes accordingly.
Line 147: Line 148:
Releases are timed to be approximately one month after GNOME releases, which are in turn about one month after releases of X.org. Consequently, every Ubuntu release comes with a newer version of both GNOME and X. Release 6.06âand recently 8.04âhave been labeled as a Long Term Support (LTS)<!-- they use the acronym and the capitals -->, to indicate support with updates for three years on the desktop and five years on the server, with paid technical support available from [[Canonical Ltd.]]<ref name="lts">{{cite web | url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-April/000065.html | title=Announcing Beta release of Ubuntu 6.06 LTS | accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref>
Releases are timed to be approximately one month after GNOME releases, which are in turn about one month after releases of X.org. Consequently, every Ubuntu release comes with a newer version of both GNOME and X. Release 6.06âand recently 8.04âhave been labeled as a Long Term Support (LTS)<!-- they use the acronym and the capitals -->, to indicate support with updates for three years on the desktop and five years on the server, with paid technical support available from [[Canonical Ltd.]]<ref name="lts">{{cite web | url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-April/000065.html | title=Announcing Beta release of Ubuntu 6.06 LTS | accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref>
â
{{create-list}}
  â
=== Ubuntu 4.10 (Warty Warthog) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-410-20080706.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 4.10<br /> (''Warty Warthog'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 4.10 (''Warty Warthog''), released on [[2004-10-20]],<ref name="warty_release" /> was Canonical's first release of Ubuntu Linux, building upon Debian GNU/Linux with plans for a new release every six months and eighteen months of support thereafter.<ref>{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2004-October/000003.html|accessdate=2008-08-19|date=[[2004-10-20]]|first=Mark|last=Shuttleworth|title=Announcing Ubuntu 4.10 "The Warty Warthog Release"}}</ref> Ubuntu 4.10's support ended on [[2006-04-30]].<ref name="warty_support">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2006-March/000061.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 reaches end of life on 30 April 2006 |date=[[2006-03-28]] |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Zimmerman |first=Matt |authorlink= }}</ref> Ubuntu 4.10 was the first version of Ubuntu to offer ShipIt services, allowing users to order free install CDs.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/WartyWarthogFinalReleaseAnnouncement| title=WartyWarthogFinalReleaseAnnouncement|date=[[2005-07-23]] |accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref> The desktop version included, among other desktop programs, [[Pidgin (software)|Gaim]] 1.0, [[GIMP]] 2.0, [[GNOME]] 2.8, [[Mozilla Firefox]] 0.9, and [[OpenOffice.org]] 1.1. The server version shipped with [[MySQL]] 4.0, [[PHP]] 4.3, and [[Python (programming language)|Python]] 2.3. Ubuntu 4.10 used [[Linux kernel|Linux]] 2.6.8 kernel with [[XFree86]] 4.3.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 5.04 (Hoary Hedgehog) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-504-20080706.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 5.04<br /> (''Hoary Hedgehog'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 5.04 (''Hoary Hedgehog''), released on [[2005-04-08]],<ref name="hoary_release">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/504 |title=5.04 Release Notes |date=2005-04-08|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> was Canonical's second release of Ubuntu Linux. Ubuntu 5.04's support ended on [[2006-10-31]].<ref name="hoary_support">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-security-announce/2006-October/000418.html |title=Ubuntu 5.04 reaches end-of-life on 31 October 2006 |date=[[2006-10-23]] |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-security-announce |last=Armstrong |first=Christina |authorlink= }}</ref> Ubuntu 5.04 added many new features including an [[Update Manager|update manager]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/upgrading|title=Upgrading your existing Ubuntu installation |accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> upgrade notifier, readahead and grepmap, suspend, [[Hibernate (OS feature)|hibernate]] and [[Standby (computers)|standby]] support, [[dynamic frequency scaling]] for processors, ubuntu hardware database, Kickstart installation, and [[Advanced Packaging Tool|APT]] authentication.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DraftHoaryReleaseAnnouncement | title=DraftHoaryReleaseAnnouncement | date=[[2005-07-31]] |accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref> Ubuntu 5.04 allowed installation from USB devices. Ubuntu 5.04 used [[UTF-8]] by default.
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 5.04 included, among other programs, [[Pidgin (software)|Gaim]] 1.1, [[GIMP]] 2.2, [[GNOME]] 2.10, [[Mozilla Firefox]] 1.0, and [[OpenOffice.org]] 1.1. The server installation included [[MySQL]] 4.0, [[PHP]] 4.3, and [[Python (programming language)|Python]] 2.4. Ubuntu 5.04 used [[Linux kernel|Linux]] 2.6.10 and [[X.Org Server|X.Org]] 6.8.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 5.10 (Breezy Badger) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-510-20080706.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 5.10<br /> (''Breezy Badger'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 5.10 (''Breezy Badger''), released on [[2005-10-13]],<ref name="breezy_release1">{{cite web | url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2005-October/000038.html | title=Ubuntu 5.10 announcement|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref><ref name="breezy_release2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/510|title=Ubuntu 5.10 release notes |accessdate=2006-12-21}}</ref> was Canonical's third release of Ubuntu Linux. Ubuntu 5.10's support ended on [[2007-04-13]].<ref name="breezy_support">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-security-announce/2007-March/000504.html |title=Ubuntu 5.10 reaches end-of-life on [[April 13]] [[2007]] |date=[[2007-03-14]] |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-security-announce |last=Heen |first=Tollef Fog |authorlink= }}</ref> Ubuntu 5.10 added several new features including a graphical bootloader ([[Usplash]]), an Add/Remove Applications tool,<ref name="add/remove">{{cite web|url= https://help.ubuntu.com/7.04/add-applications/C/gnome-app-install.html|title= Add/Remove Applications|accessdate= 2008-06-06|format= [[Wiki]]|work= Ubuntu Documentation|publisher= Canonical Ltd.}}</ref> a menu editor (alacarte), an easy language selector, [[logical volume management]] support, full [[Hewlett-Packard]] printer support, [[Original equipment manufacturer|OEM]] installer support, and [[Launchpad (website)|Launchpad]] integration for [[Software bug|bug]] reporting and software development.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/BreezyReleaseNotes | title=BreezyReleaseNotes | date=[[2005-07-31]] |accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref>
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 5.10 included, among other programs, [[Pidgin (software)|Gaim]] 1.5, [[GIMP]] 2.2, [[GNOME]] 2.12, [[Mozilla Firefox]] 1.0, and [[OpenOffice.org]] 1.9 (pre-2.0 release). The server installation included [[MySQL]] 4.1, [[PHP]] 5.0, and [[Python (programming language)|Python]] 2.4. Ubuntu 5.10 used [[Linux Kernel|Linux]] 2.6.12 and [[X.Org Server|X.Org]] 6.8.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 6.06 (Dapper Drake) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-606-20080706.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 6.06<br /> (''Dapper Drake'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 6.06 (''Dapper Drake''), released on [[2006-06-01]],<ref name="dapper_release1">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/606released | title=Ubuntu 6.06 LTS announcement |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref><ref name="dapper_release2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/606|title=Ubuntu 6.06 LTS release notes |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> was Canonical's fourth release, and the first Long Term Support (LTS) release. Ubuntu 6.06's support will end in June 2009 for desktops and June 2011 for servers. Ubuntu 6.06 included several new features, including having the [[Live CD]] and [[Install CD]] merged onto one disc,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://help.ubuntu.com/community/LiveCD|title=LiveCD - Community Ubuntu Documentation<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref> a graphical installer on Live CD ([[Ubiquity installer|Ubiquity]]), [[Usplash]] on shutdown as well as startup, a network manager for easy switching of multiple wired and wireless connections, Humanlooks theme implemented using [[Tango Desktop Project|Tango]] guidelines, based on [[Clearlooks]] and featuring orange colors instead of brown, and GDebi graphical installer for [[deb (file format)|package files]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?suite=default&section=all&arch=any&searchon=names&keywords=gdebi|title=Package gdebi|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DapperDrake | title=DapperDrake | date=[[2007-01-26]] |accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref> Ubuntu 6.06 did not include a means to install from a USB device, but did for the first time allow installation directly onto removable USB devices.
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 6.06 included, among other programs, Gaim 1.5, GIMP 2.2, GNOME 2.14, Mozilla Firefox 1.5, and OpenOffice.org 2.0. The server installation included MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.1, and Python 2.4, as well as an option to install [[LAMP (software bundle)|LAMP]]. Ubuntu 6.06 used Linux 2.6.15 and X.Org 7.0.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 6.10 (Edgy Eft) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-610-20080708.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 6.10<br /> (''Edgy Eft'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 6.10 (''Edgy Eft''), released on [[2006-10-26]],<ref name="edgy_release1">{{cite web | url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/610released | title=Ubuntu 6.10 announcement|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref><ref name="edgy_release2">{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes/610|title=Ubuntu 6.10 release notes |accessdate=2006-12-21}}</ref> was Canonical's fifth release of Ubuntu Linux. Ubuntu 6.10's support ended on [[2008-04-25]].<ref name="edgy_support">{{cite web | url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu610end-of-life | title=End of Life announcement for Ubuntu 6.10|accessdate=2008-04-01}}</ref> Ubuntu 6.10 added several new features including a heavily modified Human theme, [[Upstart]] [[init]] daemon, automated crash reports (Apport), [[Tomboy (software)|Tomboy]] note taking application, and [[F-spot]] photo manager. EasyUbuntu, a third party program designed to make Ubuntu easier to use, was included in Ubuntu 6.10 as a meta-package.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/EdgyReleaseNotes | title=EdgyReleaseNotes | date=[[2007-10-16]] |accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref>
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 6.10 included, among other programs, Gaim 2.0, GIMP 2.2, GNOME 2.16, Mozilla Firefox 2.0, and OpenOffice.org 2.0. The server installation included MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.1, and Python 2.4. Ubuntu 6.10 used Linux 2.6.17 and X.Org 7.1.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 7.04 (Feisty Fawn) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-704-20080708.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 7.04<br /> (''Feisty Fawn'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 7.04 (''Feisty Fawn''), released on [[2007-04-19]],<ref name="feisty_release">{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/FeistyFawn | title=Ubuntu 7.04 announcement|title=Ubuntu 7.04 announcement|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> was Canonical's sixth release of Ubuntu Linux. Ubuntu 7.04's support will end in October 2008. Ubuntu 7.04 included several new features, among them a migration assistant to help former [[Microsoft Windows]] users transition to Ubuntu, support for [[Kernel-based Virtual Machine]], assisted codec and restricted drivers installation, [[Compiz]] desktop effects, support for [[Wi-Fi Protected Access]], the addition of [[Sudoku]] and [[chess]], a disk usage analyzer ([[Baobab (software)|baobab]]), GNOME Control Center, and [[Zeroconf]] support for many devices.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/feistybeta | title=feistybeta | date=[[2007-03-23]] |accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref> Ubuntu 7.04 dropped support for [[PowerPC]] architecture.
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 7.04 included, among other programs, Gaim 2.0, GIMP 2.2, GNOME 2.18, Mozilla Firefox 2.0, and OpenOffice.org 2.2. The server installation included MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.2, and Python 2.5. Ubuntu 7.04 used Linux 2.6.20 and X.Org 7.2.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 7.10 (Gutsy Gibbon) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-710-20080708.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 7.10<br /> (''Gutsy Gibbon'')]] <!-- yes, the image name is incorrect as 'gusty', please do not change it or you will break the link -->
  â   â
Ubuntu 7.10 (''Gutsy Gibbon''), released on [[2007-10-18]],<ref name="gutsy_release">{{cite web | url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/GutsyReleaseSchedule | title=GutsyReleaseSchedule - Ubuntu Wiki|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref><ref name="intro_gutsy">{{cite web |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-devel-announce/2007-April/000276.html|title=Introducing the Gutsy Gibbon|date=[[2007-04-12]]|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> was Canonical's seventh release of Ubuntu Linux. Ubuntu 7.10's support will end in April 2009. Ubuntu 7.10 included several new features, among them [[AppArmor]] security framework,<ref name="tribe3">{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe3|title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 3 test release <!-- Bot generated title -->|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> fast [[desktop search]],<ref name="tribe4">{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe4|title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 4 test release <!-- Bot generated title -->|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> a firefox plug-in manager (Ubufox),<ref name="tribe5">{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe5|title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 5 test release<!-- Bot generated title -->|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> a graphical configuration tool for [[X.org]]<ref name="tribe5" /> full [[NTFS]] support (read/write) via [[NTFS-3G]], and a revamped printing system with PDF printing by default.<ref name="tribe5" /> [[Compiz Fusion]] was enabled as default in Ubuntu 7.10<ref name="tribe2">{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/testing/tribe2|title=Gutsy Gibbon - Tribe 2 test release <!-- Bot generated title -->|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> and [[Fast user switching]] was added.<ref name="tribe4" />
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 7.10 included, among other programs, GIMP 2.4, GNOME 2.20, Mozilla Firefox 2.0, OpenOffice.org 2.3, and [[Pidgin (software)|Pidgin]] 2.2. The server installation included MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.2, and Python 2.5. Ubuntu 7.10 used Linux 2.6.22 and X.Org 7.2.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 8.04 (Hardy Heron) ===
  â   â
[[Image:Ubuntu-desktop-2-804-20080708.png|left|thumb|Ubuntu 8.04<br /> (''Hardy Heron'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 8.04 (''Hardy Heron''), released on [[2008-04-24]],<ref name="hardy_release">{{cite web |url=http://www.jonobacon.org/?p=1017 | title=Introducing the Hardy Heron |accessdate=2008-08-19}}{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+milestone/ubuntu-8.04 | title=Milestone ubuntu-8.04 for Ubuntu due 2008-04-24 |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> is Canonical's eighth and latest release of Ubuntu Linux. It is the second Long Term Support (LTS) release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuWeeklyNewsletter/Issue36#head-1999d566299f6428162eb2f60acf5d12ad93f5d9|title=Ubuntu Weekly Newsletter: Issue 36|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-7344_3-6175365.html?hhTest=1&part=rss&tag=2547-1_3-0-5&subj=news|title=Ubuntu's new Linux sports debugging tool|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> Ubuntu 8.04's support will end in April 2011 for desktops and April 2013 for servers. Ubuntu 8.04 included several new features, among them [[Tracker (desktop search software)|Tracker]] desktop search integration,<ref>{{web cite|url=http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20071101-ubuntu-developer-summit-lays-out-vision-for-strong-hardy-heron-release.html |title=Ubuntu developer summit Boston|accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> [[Brasero (software)|Brasero]] disk burner,<ref name="BrasTransVin" /> [[Transmission (BitTorrent client)|Transmission]] [[BitTorrent client]],<ref name="BrasTransVin" /> [[Vinagre]] [[VNC]] client,<ref name="BrasTransVin">{{cite web|url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/hardy-changes/2008-January/004677.html|title=Accepted: ubuntu-meta 1.87 (source)|accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref> system sound through [[PulseAudio]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+spec/cleanup-audio-jumble|title=Blueprint: "Fix the Linux audio mess once and for all"|publisher=[[Launchpad (website)|Launchpad]]|accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref>, and [[Active Directory]] authentication and login using Likewise Open.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-8.04-lts-server|title=Latest Server Release Expands Ubuntu Enterprise Profile|accessdate=2008-07-05}}</ref> In addition Ubuntu 8.04 included updates for better [[Tango Desktop Project|Tango]] compliance,<ref>{{web cite |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Artwork/Incoming/Hardy |title=Hardy Heron Artwork |accessdate=2008-08-19 |publisher=Ubuntu Wiki}}</ref> various Compiz usability improvements, automatic grabbing and releasing of the mouse cursor when running on a [[VMware]] virtual machine, and an easier method to remove Ubuntu. Ubuntu 8.04 is the first version of Ubuntu to include the [[Wubi (Ubuntu)|Wubi]] installer on the Live CD that allows Ubuntu to be installed as a single file on a Windows hard drive without the need to repartition the disk.
  â   â
The desktop installation of Ubuntu 8.04 included, among other programs, GIMP 2.4, GNOME 2.22, Mozilla Firefox 3.0 Beta 5, OpenOffice.org 2.4, and Pidgin 2.4. The server installation included MySQL 5.0, PHP 5.2, Python 2.5. Ubuntu 8.04 uses Linux 2.6.24 and X.Org 7.3.
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 8.10 (Intrepid Ibex) ===
  â
{{future software}}
  â
[[Image:Ubuntu 8.10.png|right|thumb|Ubuntu 8.10 Alpha 5<br /> (''Intrepid Ibex'')]]
  â   â
Ubuntu 8.10 (''Intrepid Ibex''), to be released on [[2008-10-30]],<ref name="intrepid_release">{{cite web |url=https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+milestone/ubuntu-8.10|title=Milestone ubuntu-8.10 for Ubuntu due 2008-10-30|accessdate=2008-04-28}}</ref> will be Canonical's ninth release of Ubuntu.<ref name="warty_release" /> It will be supported until April 2010. Ubuntu 8.10 has several planned new features including a new default theme,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-art/2008-January/004855.html | title=Ubuntu theme update postponed | accessdate=2008-03-26}}</ref> improvements to mobile computing and desktop scalability, increased flexibility for Internet connectivity, a [[Graphical User Interface|GUI]] driven [[Live USB]] creator (possibly [[Live USB system creator]]), a guest account<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DesktopTeam/Specs/Intrepid/GuestAccount | title=Guest account specification | accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> and an encrypted 'private' directory in each user's home directory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.linuxloop.com/news/2008/07/03/top-5-new-features-of-ubuntu-810-interpid-ibex/ | title=Linux Loop:Top 5 New Features of Ubuntu 8.10 Intrepid Ibex |accessdate=2008-07-08}}</ref>
  â   â
=== Ubuntu 9.04 (Jaunty Jackalope) ===
  â
{{future software}}
  â   â
Ubuntu 9.04 (''Jaunty [[Jackalope]]''), to be released sometime in April 2009 will be Canonical's tenth release of the distribution. It will be supported until October 2011. Announced intended features, as of September 8, 2008, to come in this release include a faster boot time and integration of web services and applications into the desktop interface. It will also mark the first time that all of Ubuntu's core development will be moved to the [[Bazaar (software)|Bazaar]] [[Distributed revision control]] system.<ref name="ubuntu_9.04_ann">{{cite web|url= https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-devel-announce/2008-September/000481.html|title= Introducing the Jaunty Jackalope|accessdate= 2008-09-09|format= Archive|work= Mailing list archive|publisher= Canonical Ltd}}</ref>
 
=== Release history ===
=== Release history ===
